result_name: Speed of Light from Maxwell's Equations

result_equations.equation_title: Speed of Light from Maxwell's Equations

explanation: In vacuum, Maxwell's equations imply that disturbances of the electromagnetic field propagate as waves whose speed is fixed by the electric permittivity and magnetic permeability of free space. Identifying this speed with the experimentally measured speed of light shows that light is an electromagnetic wave and sets the value of the universal constant `c` from purely electric and magnetic static measurements such as the force between charges or currents.

definitions.definition: Electric field vector in vacuum (units V·m^-1).
Magnetic field vector in vacuum (units T).
Electric permittivity of free space (units F·m^-1).
Magnetic permeability of free space (units H·m^-1).
Speed of light in vacuum, equal to the propagation speed of electromagnetic waves in vacuum (units m·s^-1).

derivation.description: Start from Maxwell's equations in vacuum (no free charges or currents), in concrete with the Faraday's law and the Ampère–Maxwell law with `rho = 0` and `J = 0`.
derivation.equation: grad xx bbE = -(partial bbB)/(partial t),   grad xx bbB = mu_0*epsilon_0*(partial bbE)/(partial t)

derivation.description: Take the curl of Faraday's law to see how the curl of the electric field evolves in time.
derivation.equation: grad xx (grad xx bbE) = -(partial)/(partial t)(grad xx bbB)

derivation.description: Use the Ampère–Maxwell law in vacuum to substitute for `grad xx bbB` in the right-hand side.
derivation.equation: grad xx (grad xx bbE) = -mu_0*epsilon_0*(partial^2 bbE)/(partial t^2)

derivation.description: Apply the standard vector identity for the curl of a curl of a vector field.
derivation.equation: grad xx (grad xx bbE) = grad(grad cdot bbE) - nabla^2 bbE

derivation.description: In vacuum there is no free charge, so Gauss's law gives `grad cdot bbE = 0`.
derivation.equation: grad(grad cdot bbE) = 0 => grad xx (grad xx bbE) = -nabla^2 bbE

derivation.description: Equate the two expressions for grad xx (grad xx bbE) obtained in steps 3 and 5 to obtain the wave equation for the electric field.
derivation.equation: -nabla^2 bbE = -mu_0*epsilon_0*(partial^2 bbE)/(partial t^2)  =>  nabla^2 bbE = mu_0*epsilon_0*(partial^2 bbE)/(partial t^2)

derivation.description: Recognize this as a standard wave equation. For a wave equation of the form `nabla^2 F = (1/v^2)*(partial^2 F)/(partial t^2)`, the waves propagate with speed `v`.
Define c as the propagation speed of electromagnetic waves in vacuum and identify it with the experimentally measured speed of light.

historical_context.importance: Showed that the speed of electromagnetic waves in vacuum, computed from purely electrical and magnetic measurements, coincides with the speed of light, unifying optics with electromagnetism.
key_insights: Electromagnetic fields support wave propagation in vacuum.
The wave speed is fixed by vacuum permittivity and permeability.
The computed wave speed matches the measured speed of light.
Light is an electromagnetic wave and c is a universal constant.
